title: Devonport Striker Jazmin White takes out WSL best and fairest | The Advocate
body_text:
A shocked Jazmin White has taken out the Women's Super League's biggest individual award for the second consecutive year after another outstanding season on the pitch.
Subscribe now for unlimited access.
or signup to continue reading
The Devonport Strikers forward was named best and fairest at Football Tasmania's annual awards on Saturday, September 9.
Despite reading reports that it was a possibility, White was astounded when it was revealed she was the winner of the award.
"It was definitely a shock for me," White said
"It was just an amazing feeling seeing my name come up on the screen and it's something that I will cherish for a very long time, especially doing it back-to-back.
"I didn't think I would take it out, I thought there were other players that played really well this year."
The classy forward also took home her fifth WSL golden boot after finding the net on 33 occasions this season.
White put her success down to the team support that she received on and off the pitch.
"We did lose a few players within our team this year so we had to regroup. We had a few come up from our Northern Championship side so just having great coaching and team support is the key," she said.
It was just an amazing feeling seeing my name come up on the screen and it's something that I will cherish for a very long time, especially doing it back-to-back.
- Jazmin White
"Also training hard and putting in the effort not just on the training track but in my own time as well, and just focusing on what I can do better myself."
"It's pretty exciting because obviously we haven't played in a finals series before and I feel like at this stage in our season we are picking up a little bit more," she said.
ALSO IN SPORT
"We played the best football that we have played this year especially defensively, so we are hoping that if we do make it to that grand final we can go all the way."
The Strikers will host Launceston United from midday on Saturday, September 16 for a spot in the WSL decider.
From the men's team, Roberto Fernandez Garrido took out NPL Tasmania's golden boot, player's player and the Walter Pless Medal.
